Share any unusual traditions or locations on campus

Security on duty all day everyday, patrol campus regularly, emergency call boxs on every building on campus. Wherever you are on campus you can see a blue light that shows where the emergency call boxes are located.

We have four social soroities (Alpha Chi Omega, Sigma Sigma Sigma, Kappa Delta, and Alpha Sigma Alpha) and four social fraternities (Sigma Nu, Phi Delta Theta, Delta Sigma Theta, and Sigma Phi Epsilon)
There is a club for anything and everything you can think of and if we don't have it, then you can make it happen.
Beaver Point is an on campus cabin near the lake that students can go to study, throw horseshoes or play volleyball. The location is often reserved by clubs and organizations for events.

There are a ton of on campus activities sponsored by the college. The college often has deals with local businesses so that students can also have a little free/cheap off campus fun. Such as, kings dominion trips, bowling nights, Hillcats games, etc.

There are a lot of options as to where students can eat. The cafeteria has fresh food everyday and a make-your-own sandwich and salad bar with lunch meats from Boars Head. Westover, where students can use meal exchanges, have multiple meal options. Brewed Awakenings is a little cafe located in an academic building. The Hornet Shop, that also allows meal exchanges, have quick meals to grab in between classes. Finally, Rollie Polie, a local sandwich shop, serves wraps and stays open late.

The dorm rooms are pretty big compared to the other colleges that I looked at. Cleaning people are really nice. There are a lot of options for where you can live. There are 2 freshman dorms, 4 upper-classman dorms, 2 apartment buildings and a lot of on campus houses that upper-classman can live in as well.
Lynchburg College was the best choice for me. The professors are hands on and know you by name. It's easy to concentrate with less people in each class.

textAfterTable: Bang for the buck LC offers great scholarships, especially for in-state residents. Make sure you keep pushing the Financial Aid office looking for more scholarships; usually they will offer more if you insist. For the price of the school (or any price really), you are getting a great education. Am enjoying being here The people at LC are very friendly and open. Because the campus is relatively small (about 2,000 undergrads), it's hard to walk anywhere without seeing someone you know.
